author: Thoamos

title: Ultimate Skylark Antenna tracker all in one box!

description.text:
UPDATE:1/11/2016 The JR Module now fits the EZUHF module which was larger than the DTF that I was using, The clips where the module locks into have been adjusted so they work with all JR modules.(it actually makes a nice snap lock noise) I've been using this all in one box for over 12 months now, this box has both video and RC control pointed at the plane at all times. This literally means the sky is the limit :) This all in one box will bolt straight up to the Skylark Antenna tracker, and probably would work the same with the My fly dream antenna tracker. The tracker doesn’t struggle at all with this setup and I’ll be posting a video shortly of how it performs. Running video
https://youtu.be/SbkTmRkjKxs The way it works My Frsky taranis TX talks to a 2.4 RX running in SBUS, then the 2.4 frksy RX sends SBUS to the OpenLRS UHF JR TX module which then talks to the plane UHF RX. You could set this up running CPPM as well if you didn't want to use SBUS. I have a 3s Lipo running the tracker, a 2s Lipo running the Video RX, Frsky 2.4 RX and JR openLRS UHF module. I used a 2s to avoid using a BEC and yes there is power that could be used from the antenna tracker but you'll get noise from the Tracker. Using the power from the tracker will result with lines through the Video, the PCB tracks are very small on the Antenna tracker PCB so using a different battery for the all in one box and tracker is a must. Assembly It's almost impossible to assemble this incorrectly as there are cut outs in the base where the parts mount into. Put the JR module part on the base first, then add both sides, super glue all that together, then glue the end plate. Nylock nuts were used in the Box sides to screw down the lid but anything could be used as long it’s the same size. I cut the RCA ends off my video RX cable, I installed female RCA inputs into the box and then soldered the wires to the correct female plugs. A DC plug is at the end of the box which powers up all the Video and RC control gear. Printing
The parts infill can be pretty much whatever you want it to be. I did print most things at 90% Moxon Antenna If you’re wondering how good this antenna works, I’ve been out to 23k(one way) with no packet loss and could have gone much further.
The right side of the Moxon antenna needs to be printed with Support material, everything else is printed without. The Moxon can be mounted either horizontal or vertical to match your FPV aircraft. The wire used on the Moxon was 20 gauge magnet wire bought from EBAY, I then used a pigtail extension which goes from the JR module to the Moxon. Wires have to be soldered on the Moxon end (Antenna elements) The DTFUHF deluxe only needs to be printed if you are using that module instead of the JR, I had both so I made it for both. Any questions please post and I’ll be happy to answer.

title: Dewalt Lithium Ion 20 Volt Adapter to RYOBI One+ 18 volt tools

description.text: Due to the fact that I use Dewalt cordless tools, I have created an adapter to use a Dewalt 20v Lithium Ion Battery with my 18v RYOBI One+ hedge trimmer DISCLAIMER/WARNING - Use at your own Risk. it can be Dangerous to over discharge Lithium batteries. -Risk of Fire or Explosion- The 20V Tools that use this type of Lithium battery have the battery protection circuitry inside the tools, not the battery, and as such the user of this adapter must be careful not to over discharge the battery.

Printer:

Makergear M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% or higher

Notes: I did not need supports for the top (18v) part, or the side clips, however it is nessecary to use support on the bottom (20v) part. It prints upside down.

Assembly The contacts locations are set up to use blue automotive spade terminals. the top (18V) connections you will need to remove the insulators. Soldering the wires is required, as the connectors deform too much if you crimp them. the parts are set up to have the terminals Glued in place (i used superglue) you will need 4x #6-32 x 1/2" machine screws to assemble the tob and bottom half.
I used a spring out of a click pen, cut in half) for the side clips. The clips are held in place by the top and bottom half.

comments.text:
Works great with a little tweaking!
Fits a bit loose on the Ryobi side. It works fine as-is, but could fit tighter.
The spade connector mounts could use some work. The upper ones are a bit too far recessed, too narrow, and could use a back to glue them too. The lower ones barely touch the Dewalt contacts, and need to be shifted slightly closer for a solid connection.
The clips dont squeeze in far enough to release reliably, so I printed them at 75% scale on the Z axis to make them thinner.
The clip STL file is at a weird slight angle. It has to be rotated 2.5 degrees to sit flat on the bed.

comments.author: SCHEMENKE

comments.text: The balance connector is a connection to each of the individual 3.7v  (3.3v to 3.8v depending on battery type) cells as well as the ground connector. The Dewalt 20V batteries (and all other LiIon batteries) have  these connections as a part of their connectors.  Yes it would be easier to just have a monitor for the total voltage, however typically the discharge of each cell is different and if you dont monitor all of the cells, you could potentially have one cell bellow 3.3v and still be above 17V total.

I miss my days of a phone cradle. And being as I destroy phones I am stuck with using a huge case and would never be able to use a regular one anyway. This fits my EVO well with the otter box on it. Just shove the data cable in the hole (mine was not the original HTC one) and slide the phone in. It could be heavier, but serves its purpose well. I printed this on my UP!. It was a tight fit, thus the reason the bottom is slightly sized down as I print in ABS and the platform would hit my tray slides. Almost forgot.
The door to the port on the case will have to be removed for this to work. Every otterbox case I have owned has had this fall off within a couple months. Mine has been gone for a while already so it almost didn't cross my mind.

This is a printout of 14th century font, thanks to scans from Usher Gallery and The Collection in Lincoln, see http://lincoln3dscans.co.uk/font-two/ To be more printable, i cut the object into two parts at the spot, where the original is joined. Then, the upper part with the basin was also cut a bit and the inner part was flattened, additionaly, i added support structures with meshmixer. Recommendedn slicing settings (slic3er): 200um, PLA, infill 5% hexagonal, for the basin, i recommend the circular top/bottom fill patern, it looks more natural. Printed in black PLA and glued together with 5 minute epoxy. The only empty section on the leg alligns against the only sign section of the basin .
Drybrushed the details with acrylic grey and white.
I never saw the original, it should be limestone, so my color choice is probably wrong, but anyway, i like it:D Many thanks to Lincoln for their 3D scans project, exceptional ! Update: I created another font, please check http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1280967

description.text:
This is a mix of the very nice clip done by Madox; the filament hole was too snug and we wanted the filament to travel freely - allowing us to mount the clip anywhere on the spool.   
We redid the filament hole to be 4mm and have nice thick walls to ensure a strong, flexible piece.  
Using a clip has made a night and day difference between tangled spools or not - we change filament spools a lot, so for us was a must.

title: Stablized and Higher Cord Reel Spool Riser Clip

description.text:
I love, love, love our new filament management via cord reels and jag's spool riser design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5792). However, I had three problems with his design:
  • if I printed them thin, they weren't very stable
  • if I printed them thick enough to be stable, it was really hard to remove the spools--we have lots of colors so switching is common.
  • the risers were a bit low, making changing the filament difficult if the z-stage was all of the way up.
    • So, I modified his design (thanks for the source file, jag!) to add a stable base and raise it higher. They work perfectly.

• print 2 LEFTs and 2 Rights
  • place them on the middle of the one of the sides (on top where there's a big notch) and side them over so they hook securely under the edge.

title: 2 or 4 Slice SD Toaster (with optional wings)

description.text:
I enjoyed ThunderMuffin's SD card toaster idea, and made my own design.  2 or 4 slice versions, full size SD cards.  
There's a hole on the bottom plate for a round rare earth magnet
I added a pair of wings. Because After Dark.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Wings should not need supports if printed in the orientation in the STL-- However, they may be fragile during printing due to the small contact area with the buildplate. Brim is recommended. Also, I positioned them so they just barely touch. If you print with no retraction, the stringing will act as cross supports and help the two wings support each other while printing.

author: lanimal

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aCeo5Kh0XrI

This initial design wasn't made for combat but for more usability as one of the problems with the air frame is trying to find a home for everything when used in an FPV configuration. It turns out that this design has proven to be very tough and has taken some serious beatings without braking any of the 3D printed parts. Print all parts solid for durability, Zip ties hold the base plate to the frame. I used some thin adhesive foam on the base plate to make a really nice secure fit, you wouldn't have to use this but it makes a nice seal. 2 x nylock nuts are put into the base and then glue the Nylock covers to the base making sure that the bolt can pass through the nylock cover hole, these covers are so the nuts don't fall out when securing the top FPVgear lid to the base. You'll need to print 2 of the VTX sides, this offers maximum protection for the Video transmitter.
Everything was put together using super glue, the FPVgear base lid has holes for all the different parts for easy quick assembly. Any questions please ask.

Remodel / copy of burhop's design using my path extrude script. A slice of the nut has also been taken out to make the internal mechanism more obvious.
The half-size version is reduced in size with a slightly steeper angle, but has the same printing clearance between the nut and bolt.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Vr_H3YAPTH8" ></iframe>
Printed full-size model in HIPS with 4mm clearance. Some cleaning of screw threads was required to get it to turn

This is a remix of the Shuttle and Booster Tank from the Autodesk 123D Gallery. They are interesting (albeit somewhat fanciful) models, but there was no way to connect the two together! I modeled a set of sliding connectors (female and male) and integrated them with the shuttle and tank using Tinkercad. Since I was doing it, I put a connector on both sides of the booster, that way you can launch two shuttles at once.

I've uploaded the plate files that contain the tank and shuttle split into segments, so they should print easily. Use support material to be sure, though I don't think the shuttle needs it.  
The whole thing would probably benefit from being scaled up before printing 150% or 200%. Many details are too fragile at the current size.  
I will probably edit the booster tank model to make the nozzles far more robust, they are currently too fragile to make a good toy.

comments.text: By the way this is the booster rocket of Buran, the Soviet space shuttle that flew one unmanned orbital flight before the project got shot after the collapse of the USSR.
comments.author: NeuroFab

comments.text: The booster rocket was named Energia, the shuttle was named Buran. Energia was capable of launching without the Buran shuttle, where it could deliver things like massive nuclear reactor powered laser satellites into orbit. (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyus_(spacecraft%29 )

description.text:
Thing #4113 is still fiddly to undo, so I decided to make it easier to use.
This bolt knob is larger and has improved geometry to grip on with the fingers. This design also makes it easier to use as the screw head is fixed on the other side of the knob comparing to the thing #4113, minimizing the risk of breaking off while being tightened.
Because screw comes through the whole length of the thing there is no need to use epoxy to secure the screw. One drop of super glue is enough. And when you do it up it will only become better.
Unfortunately, It takes longer screws. I used 1 inch long M3 screws with hex socket head 5mm in diameter. But these are standard and easy to get.
Hope I just made world a little bit better :-)

title: Improved ReprapDiscount Hall Effect Mount for Makerslide / Ord printers

description.text:
These are some mounts I made by modifying GearNut's original mounts.  These mounts have a small plug in the end of the groves that hold the sensor, to help prevent the sensor from moving around.  
I have also added a 1mm thick tab to the back of the mount to help people print these on printers that have a moving print bed.  I found that the oscillation of the bed during printing made it difficult to complete the print of the original mount without it loosing adheasion with the bed and falling over part way through the print.  Once the print has cooled, the tab can be easily snapped off of the mount.  
I plan on modifying this mount  further by adding a slight groove in the back of the mount to prevent the connector pins from blocking the sensor board as it slides into the mount.

author: ingoord

description.text:
A group of us indoor FPV race nano QX's weekly. All are showing motor failures after 4-5 hours airtime and spares are either ludicrously priced, or on the slow boat from China. Based on the frame layout of the FireFlo, I wanted to shave some weight off a mono-deck for nano QX board and camera, paired with low-cost Hubsan 7mm motors & props. The result is this Gnat QX, with the frame weighing in at a mere 3g. AUW without pack is 24g, 6g heavier than stock. Power is exceptional in comparison to EFlites 6mm motors. Edit:
v1.1 - added a second loom band clip for more secure battery fixture
v2 - extended arms slightly (optional change to try and remove a small wobble) Have found there is a huge variety of Hubsan motors/props all claiming to be genuine. Mine flys well on 7 x 20mm hollow cups with props that came with motors. Friends have had trouble with other props so working on a mini bullnose prop trimmer for adjustment. Edit2:
Added 2 new motor cap designs and a beefed up v3 chassis - the extra weight at the motors, stiffer frame and 300mAh batteries bring the AUW up to 35g, but eliminate the wobble. Try a small piece of foam or thin neoprene between the frame and battery - it stops the battery touching the motor connectors. Edit3: v4 added with band hooks to hold camera more securely and a small stinger to act as strain relief for the battery wiring. Edit4: after several requests, added an 8.5 mm motor variant for use with Hubsan parts. These motors will probably destroy a stock Nano QX flight controller. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvO3es128r4 Edit5: added another version of this frame (Gnat–F3) aimed specifically at the new breed of F3 flight controllers, such as the Kylin from Banggood: http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-SKYkylin-F3-Brushed-Flight-Control-Board-Built-in-FRSKY-Compatible-8CH-Receiver-p-1100694.html?p=JN120678599082016128

title: Rostock Max V2 simple spool holder

description.text:
Simple spool holder for an otherwise stock Rostock Max V2 printer. Not sure how the spool holder looks on older Rostock Max printers, but it might work for them as well.
Just print two of these and mount opposite each other on the original spool holder (snug fit), adjust to fit the width of your filament-spool.
This was made for my first spool which had a hole diameter of 50 mm (radius on this part is 23 mm) but should do its job for most hole diameters.
Using this part the spool turns smoothly, eliminating any "sticking and jerking" that the stock holder causes.

edmo's 2 liter bottle watering spout. Since I water my plants with a gallon jug of spring water instead of a 2 liter bottle, I wanted an adapter that would fit that.

The built-in fan-mount on the Sintron Kossel end-effector design was not that good. It was coming in the way of the diagonal rod-ends. Also, the draft from the fan was going all over the place, and cooling things that were not supposed to be cooled. However, this design turns out to be much better, as it mounts directly on the hot-end heat-sink. I was able to customize it, for a 30mm fan, and a heat-sink barrel diameter of 19.5mm (which is much smaller than the original E3D V6 hot-end, as this is a clone). This design cools the hot-end heat-sink barrel much more effectively, so the nozzle heats up faster, and the prints seem to come out so much better. Also, since there are no gaps on the top or bottom of the fan-mount, all of the air is completely forced directed only towards the heat-sink, which is awesome. title: Windowed Front Panel for Mini Fabrikator 3D Printer By Tiny Boy

description.text:
A front panel for the Turnigy Mini Fabrikator 3D Printer By Tiny Boy with a big window that allows for easier access to printed parts and the Y gantry.
It is designed to be cut by laser from 3mm acrylic glas.
Please note that this will probably not work with the original Tiny Boy since the HobbyKing clone is 1cm higher than the original.

It's easy replace the original front with this by just removing the four screws and replacing the sheet of acrylic glas. The printer itself will not fall apart if you just remove those four screws.
Don't try to force it on the tabs, because it might break. If it doesn't fit, it might help to use a fine rasp to widen the holes a little.

description.text: This is the shape of a rhombic dodecahedron divided into four identical pieces in an unintuitive way. Luckily you don't need to be familiar with the final shape: when you discover how to fit the pieces together they will converge into a rhombic dodecahedron. Here's a YouTube video showing how the puzzle fits together: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MpmkWj1LPwE It's also described in my blog at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2011/10/rhombic-dodecahedron-puzzle.html
Build four identical copies of the STL file, then try to assemble them. The STL file is generated by the OpenSCAD script Rhombic270.scad using the DXF drawing spiral270.dxf

Convert your Glue Stick into a Linear Actuator!

Video: https://youtu.be/0SEahIQyB8A
If you are into 3D printing, chances are you have a bunch of used glue sticks lying around, the best way to get your prints to stick on your print beds. Why throw it away? Turn it into a linear actuator!
After toying around with several designs, I finally simplified it to a basic minimalistic design.
This is made for a "UHU" brand, large 21g glue stick. You can probably scale it to fit other brands or sizes. As you can see in the pictures, mine is a special edition with a picture of a minion on it ;-) You do not need to get one with a minion on it but in case you do, do not place it near a banana.
You'll need a continuous servo for this. You can easily find instructions on the net to modify a standard servo into a continuous servo. I have a tutorial on my blog showing an alternative way to modify one while leaving the pot exposed to make fine adjustments or to use it as speed control. You can check it out here: http://www.kikitayblog.com/2012/07/electronics-new-way-of-modifying.html
Assembly is pretty straightforward, as you can see in the picture. You'll need to glue the shaft to the bottom inside the tube. I've included 2 versions of the larger gear. One can be print it as a single piece, the other can be printed in 2 pieces without support, but you'll have to glue them together. You'll only need to print one of these gears.
All the screws used in the design are M4 size except for the servo horn. Use the screw that comes with your servo.
Tips:

  • As there are no limit switches inside the glue stick, make sure you don't turn below or beyond its maximum points. One method is to loosen the grip on the glue stick. So that once it reaches its limit, the entire stick has room to rotate.

  • When trying to fit the gear horn onto the servo, I would use a soldering iron to heat up the servo shaft a little so that the geared horn could soften/melt slightly and form a tight fit when it cools. Of course only do this only if you're using a metal gear servo, for obvious reason :-P

  • I've also included a gear horn without a centre hole so that you can drill it to fit your desired size. Use my "Simple Center Finder" to accurately find the center of the gear: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1241609

  • The top of the shaft has a mounting hole for an M4 size screw. You can use it to mount your object or a platform to it. I've also included one without a mounting hole. You can drill it to your specific size.

  • Notice the shaft has 3 grooves along its side. You will find that your glue stick has 3 tracks inside that you'll need to align it with.
    • STL Files:
    1. Glue_StickActuator-_Printbed.stl - Print-bed-ready file. Print the entire assembly on a single print bed.
    2. Servo_Bracket.stl - Servo holder + Glue Stick holder.
    3. Large_Gear_Split.stl - Large gear to rotate the bottom of the glue stick. Prints without support but requires sticking the two parts together
    4. Large_Gear.stl - Large gear to rotate the bottom of the glue stick. May require support.
    5. Small_Gear.stl - Small gear to fit onto your servo. Refer to the tips above to better secure it to your servo.
    6. Shaft.stl - Fits inside your glue stick where your glue is supposed to be. Has a hole on top to mount object or platform. Requires M4 size screw.
    7. Shaft_Without_Mounting_Hole.stl - Same as above, except without a mounting hole.


    Remember to share your prints or project!
    Click on my profile to see my other designs!
    Check out my blog: http://www.KikiTayBlog.com

I've now cut, tested and fixed the design so it now works. The one in the pictures is made of 2mm perspex (from the scrap material pile). The door at the bottom is made from 5mm perspex to add strength, 2mm worked, but just seems to flimsy to have a 3 year old grabbing. The crazing was due to the material being too cold when cutting and so overstressing with the laser heat. If you have the same problem, just put the pieces in the oven at 100-110C for 50 minutes, then leave to cool slowly, this removes the stress and stops it cracking when using solvent cement to glue it. I should be uploading a better looking one, once I've tested it under use by an over excitable 3 year old. https://youtu.be/g9Ga7IZQuYw apologies for the poor camera skills. :~)

This is a project I am currently building for a friend with a young child. They are trying to improve their behaviour, but wanted something a bit more fun than a sticker chart.
It has an A4 footprint, so should be cuttable in most laser cutters.
The coin slot first gets mounted on the wall. Every time the child is deserving of a reward they get a coin. They then get to watch it tumble down through the ramps when they put it in. At the end of the day (or even better the next morning) they get count up there score, before opening the door at the bottom and letting the coins back out, preferably into a bag!
This should be more effective than a sticker chart. The coin can be given immediately, even when they cant put it in the slot till later (eg good behaviour in the car). The visual effect of the coin bouncing down also acts as a reward in itself to many youngsters. Finally, they can save up points to 'buy' a reward. This helps reinforce the positive nature of the game, as well as building a sense of how money and saving works (do they want a trip to go to the park today, or save some more and get a toy they really want).
The design in semi parametric. It should scale reasonably well around it's current size, but might create some weird problems with extremes (particularly smaller sizes). So double check it is sane if you change much.
It is currently sized for 2mm thick perspex and takes 25 2 pence (UK) coins, but is easy to change both of these to whatever you have to hand (coins or tokens). The slope can also be changed to improve reliability at the cost of greater height.
I hopefully should have some pictures soon, once I've cut and tested it.

title: Monoprice Maker Select i3 Proximity Mount

description.text:
EDIT: I have done some testing with this bracket and I have decided that it is inadequate. It is not due to the bracket but due to the design of the X carriage. If the nozzle contacts the bed before the inductive sensor is triggered the carriage is rotated in such a way that the sensor is lifted away from the bed. The causes the nozzle to be driven further into the bed. A redesign is in the works! This part was created to mount a LJ18A3-8-Z/BX inductive proximity sensor to the X carriage of a Maker Select or Wanhao Duplicator i3. The hole for the sensor is approximately 18 mm but I have included the FreeCAD file so anyone can modify this as they wish. The bracket is mounted to the carriage on top of where the stock filament cooling fan goes using two (2) M3 hex cap bolts, two (2) washers per bolt, and two (2) wingnuts. The bolts you use should be at least 10 mm long, depending on your cooler. I designed the bracket to be compatible with the stock cooling fan and also the DiiiCooler for Wanhao Duplicator i3 that can be found on Thingivers. Required Hardware:
2 M3x11mm (or longer)
4 M3 Washers
2 M3 wingnuts, standard nuts, or nyloc nuts

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3 mm

Infill:

50% or more

Notes: I printed the bracket in ABS with 0.1 mm layers and 100% infill. I used Cura to slice and print and I scaled the print by 1% before slicing. All dimensions of the print are accurate to ±0.1 mm and most are ±0.05.

comments.text: Is it easy to add the Proximity Sensor for auto leveling (Provided the bracket works?) I was thinking about getting the Wanaho Duplicator I3, but would like to have auto leveling to make life easier. Maybe you can add a section on how to install, if it wouldn't be too much trouble. Haven't found anything anywhere else, Unless if you have a lead on how to install. Thanks!
comments.author: 3dprintedworkshop

comments.text: Setting up auto leveling isn't too hard. I followed a post on Instructables and made a few modifications. That being said, and as I have noted in the description on this bracket, I don't think this thing should be used for auto leveling. When using this bracket, if the nozzle contacts the bed at any point before the sensor is activated there could be a catastrophic failure where the nozzle is driven further into the bed until the printer is turned off. I was working on a new bracket but got too busy with my job and the bracket got put on hold. I don't mind adding your requests, it will just have to come at a later time.

title: StopGlass v1.0 K8200
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Descrizione in italiano:
Questo mia creazione è utilizzabile solo su stampanti in 3D che montano un piatto riscaldato 7350-3dheaterplate con ovviamente il piatto di vetro soprastante. Questo è dovuto al fatto che i fori del suddetto piatto sono all'estremità e perciò è semplice l'applicazione dello StopGlass senza problemi. Lo StopGlass ha tre vantaggi:
  • Non ostacola l'Hot-End perché l'altezza dello StopGlass è al livello del piatto;
  • Riesce a tenere saldamente il piatto vetrato;
  • Il piatto vetrato è facilmente rimovibile verso l'alto e quindi pratico;
    • Istruzioni:
    Devono essere stampati due pezzi che verranno posizionati ai vertici opposti. Il montaggio consiste nello svitare le viti del piatto riscaldato interessate, con la successiva rimozione dell'anello dentato e l'aggiunta dello StopGlass . Deve essere posto sotto il piatto d'alluminio della stampante orientato nel modo in cui viene stampato.
    Preferibilmente in ABS.     Importante:
    In download è presente la versione con il foro per la vite e non. Nel secondo quindi bisogna effettuarlo da per se con una punta da 3 mm (con una punta da legno preferibilmente) tramite l'utilizzo di un trapano a colonna o trapano normale. Il foro deve essere eseguito nel punto preciso in cui voi volete, tenendo conto del piatto Questa non è una versione che può essere soggetta a modifiche da parte della community e non commerciabile. Il sottoscritto non si assume la responsabilità per eventuali danni che può provocare lo StopGlass. L'idea mi è venuta guardando i video di SgaboLab. Consiglio di vedere il suo canale di YouTube Description in English:
    This my creation can only be used on printers 3D that mount a plate heated 7350-3dheaterplate with of course the glass plate above. This is due to the fact that the holes of the said plate are end and therefore is simple application of the StopGlass without problems. The StopGlass has three advantages:
  • It does not hinder Hot-End because the height of StopGlass is at the level of the flat
  • Can you hold firmly plate glass
  • The flat glass is easily removable upwards and then practical
    • Instructions:
    Must be printed two pieces that will be placed at the diagonal corners . The assembly is to unscrew screws heated plate concerned , with the subsequent removal ring gear and the addition of the StopGlass . It must be placed under the aluminum tray of the printer oriented in the way it is printed.
    Preferably ABS.     Important:
    In downloads is present a version with the screw hole and not .In the second so you have to maintain it by itself with a 3mm bit (with a wood drill bit preferably ) through the use of a drill or drill normal. The hole must be performed in the exact spot where you want, taking into account the plate This is not a version that may be subject to change by the community and not marketable. The undersigned does not assume responsibility for any damage that may result in the StopGlass. The idea came to me watching video footage of SgaboLab. Council to see his YouTube channel

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Used as a protractor, it allows you to divide a work piece.
Instructions I had an old Atlas lathe with one of these degree wheels on the back of the chuck, used it often and now I miss it. So I made one for this mini lathe. The 4 inch diameter wheel has a hole every 5 degrees. I designed it with zero-clearance and, as a result, it is conveniently attached by a tight slip-fit over a spindle retaining nut on the rear of the spindle.
The pointer bracket is just a basic pointer-holder at this time. I'm not quite sure how or where I want to attach the pointer thing. A short length of aluminum rod is shown. Both parts were "test" printed with Afinia default settings (basically medium speed and 0.30mm Z-resolution) and came out better than expected, so that's good enough for now.
The ring's small holes were well defined and surprisingly it showed no signs of warping or of wanting to lift. Perhaps that part is due to the relief I gave it. I did use a raft. The bracket doesn't need a raft since only a small area touches the build platform, and to conserve filament I did not use one there.
Roughly 30g for the ring and 18g for the bracket. Since the lathe's gear case cover must be removed to use this device, I used its two threaded attachment holes to bolt the pointer-bracket on with a couple of short 5mm x 0.80 bolts. These lathes are regularly modified by the factories with slight differences season to season, and there's no telling if this thing will fit anyone's 7X mini lathe, but I suspect it very often will. [Update]
Metric files have been provided, around Dec, 2016 so... Merry Christmas, Happy holidays

comments.author: knwest

description.text: I have posted this before but I have made a change I was using foam for the bottom of my feet and changed to silicone man what a difference the printer went to a all most a full quite all I can hear now is the fans.And the most impressive improvement was the results of the prints afterwards, what an improvement. Turns out that all the vibrations from everything effects the print and the feet got rid of all of this.So I am here to let you know you got to at least try the feet if not mine some others. You will be impressed as well. Hope this helps. Happy printing. :-) Created with Design Spark Mechanical. http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical Robert KB3LNN

Want a compact multi-device charging station? This USB Charging Station has been developed in TinkerCad and is designed to except USB Charger RAVPower 40W 4-Port USB Desktop Wall Charger Charging Station available from amazon, link: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OT6YUIY?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00, and provide three(3) resting platforms for devices and a hook for a Bluetooth headset.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Built on blue painters tape with an extrusion head temperature of 210C, a heated bed temperature at 70C, travel speed set at 45 and fan on after the first two layers. Ambient room temperature is on the cool side mid to low 60F.

USB Charging Station Pictures The pictured USB Charging Station has been printed in Proto-Pasta Coffee PLA which has been wonderful to work with. Silky smooth extrusion in a rich brown color and an added bonus is it smells like brewing coffee while printing.

The USB Charging Station Printed Components The USB Charging Station has three separate printed components. The first component is the base "USB Charging Station A.stl" which has a breakout piece for the USB connections. platform area for rubber feet and a hole for the charging cable to pass through. The second component "USB Charging Station B.stl" is the top to be secured to the base, I used super glue and clamps to secure the two pieces together. Because of the large flat surface on part B be cautious of warping. I would recommend cooling completely before removing from build platform. The third component is optional and is the Bluetooth headset hanger which is attached with double-sided tape and can be placed anywhere along the back. I chose the center. I hope you enjoy the build and let me know if you have any questions.

If you own more DualShock 4 controllers for your Sony Playstation 4, this is the perfect solution to keep them well organized.
This multiple stand is very compact and you can even place it just above the Playstation 4.
It allows easy access to the micro-USB port of each controller, so you can recharge each controller keeping them in place on the stand. NEW UPDATES:

  • The bases have been redesigned to give them more robustness.
  • Now you can easly stick rubber bumpers under the base to make it more stable.

comments.text:
Hi Gavin, thank you for your feedback.
I have modelled the PS4 controller using a semirigid metallic wire in order to shape the main curves of its external body.
Then I have taken a photo of each shaped wire placed on a flat white paper and I have imported the pictures into my preferred 3D modelling software: MoI 3D.
So I have created few basic curves matching the shapes of the metallic wires...
I guess you could easly replicate this tecnique to model any other complex object ;-)

This is a mechanical watch with tourbillon driven by a 3d-printed mainspring. The watch has a Swiss lever escapement. The mainspring inside the going barrel keeps the watch running for approximately 30-45 Minutes. Accuracy is roughly one Second deviation within one Minute (depending on print-settings). The project demonstrates that the 3D-printing technology is developing. Compared with earlier generations of 3d-printers, the process works more reliable and more accurately. However it's still a very advanced project, because printing inaccuracies need to be trimmed manually with some watchmaker skills, or the watch won't tick. The watch is designed with Autodesk Fusion 360, and printed with Ultimaker 2. How it's made:
https://youtu.be/Go8woPGOggg Assembly:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiZAEaES2Ng
https://jig.space/view?jig=728 (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/greenlig) Assembly Time Lapse:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s3p25T6YlQc Autodesk Fusion 360 Design:
http://a360.co/1S4wp4W (all parts assembled)
http://a360.co/1KUNz3g (main spring relaxed) Many thanks to Nicholas Manousos for his great article in HODINKEE explaining the importance of my project from a watchmakers perspective. His first 3d-printed Tourbillon 1000% was also a source of inspiration for my work.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal (cura defaults)

Infill:

30%

Notes: 0.4 mm Nozzle Only the Pawl Unlock Key needs to be printed with support. Hairspring, Anchor, Escapement Wheel, and some gears were printed with high resolution (0.06mm layer, 0.8mm shell). All other parts are printed with normal resolution (0.1mm layer, 0.8mm shell). The infill of the anchor is 80% in order to have a better balanced center of gravity (rest has 30% infill). For the case I used PETG (slightly bendable, shock absorbing), and the gears are printed with PLA (harder and less friction). In colors: black and yellow parts are PETG, orange and red parts are PLA. The Mainspring is printed with PETG (PLA probably breaks after a while). I switched off "combing" in Cura. While this is a cool feature for regular shaped parts, it causes problems with large spiral shaped parts: The print-head does many useless long (2 meters!) travelling moves. Printing not only takes 30% longer, it oozes during the move, and when continuing to print, the nozzle is empty of material, and the resulting under-extrusion is disastrous. The Hairspring needs to be printed in PLA. Other material basically work as well, but due to different stiffness, it's expected, that the watch runs too slow, or too fast. The design of the spring needs to be changed depending on the material. Printing on heated glass-bed. Used a mix of alcohol and water to clean it. Adhesion is exceptional. For removing the parts from the build plate I poured a few drops of the same alcohol mix into the groove between plastique and glass. The effect is miraculous and the part can be removed immediately without applying any force. Make sure x- and y-axis of your printer are adjusted really square! My Ultimaker wasn't fabricated good enough (1-2mm slant) - the result were oval Minutes and Hours wheel, and they jammed at some angles.

Watch this video, if you like to understand, how the watch is constructed. These are all the Parts needed. 51 downloadable and printable, and some Pins and Screws. Part List:
  • 1 Pin, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 55.5 mm (tourbillon axis)
  • 1 Pin, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 12 mm (anchor axis)
  • 1 Pin, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 8.5 mm (planet gear axis)
  • 3 Pins, Diameter 2 mm, Length 57 mm (axis for pinions for minutes and hours wheel)
  • 6 Pins, Diameter 2 mm, Length 22 mm (axis for basic transmission)
  • 1 Pin, Diameter 2 mm, Length 15 mm (attachment main spring)
  • 1 Pin, Diameter 3 mm, Length 22.5 mm (axis for main spring)

  • 1 Pin, Diameter 3 mm, Length 31 mm (axis for main pinion)

  • 3 Washers, Diameter 3 mm (main spring, pinion)
  • 6 Washers, Diameter 2 mm (transmission)

  • 5 Washers, Diameter 1.5 mm (tourbillon, escapement)

  • 5 Screws, Diameter 1.8 mm, Length 6.5 mm (ratchet pawls)
  • 5 Screws, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 5 mm (going barrel)
  • 4 Screws, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 10 mm (base plate)
  • 4 Screws, Diameter 1.8 mm, Length 12 mm (clock face)
  • 3 Screws, Diameter 1.5 mm, Length 10 mm (tourbillon cage)
    • Small holes are usually not very accurately printed. Use a drill to smooth the inner surface - especially the Balance Wheel needs to rotate with very little friction, and very little play. If you don't find pins or screws with the recommended diameter, you can certainly use little larger pieces - there is some "meet" which can be drilled out. Assembly: Spring Barrel Assembly: Align the Barrel like in the picture below. It will then slide into the case like in the video (2:49). The Pawl Unlock Key is also a useful tool to keep the pawls in place during this assembly step. Besides the Winding Key there is also a Key to unlock the Ratchet Pawls. I recommend to fully unwind/relax the Main Spring, when the watch is not used. It certainly will extend the life-time. Have fun! :-)

comments.text: @TheGoofy - Got a solution for the drill thing. Basically I used a drill bit in a pin vise which is just fitting/very slightly smaller than the pin. Then I force a pin longer than the hole depth and attach it to my dremel. I spin it and it melts the plastic. It needs to be steady and you must not hold it there too long. Don't leave the pin in there after you are done as the melted plastic will stick onto the pin. Let it cool and resolidify before placing it at desired placement. At the end the gap is just enough for movement yet not large such that it introduces shake.
comments.author: kwhor

comments.text: I've printed hairsprings in PLA of PETG - both work. Since PLA is stiffer, a PLA-spring with the same dimensions ticks faster than a PETG-spring. If you turn the balance wheel by 15° or more, the hairspring must be able to move it back. If not, there is still too much friction in the bearing of the balance wheel. Ideally the balance wheel should oscillate a couple of times on its own, before it stops.
comments.author: kwhor

comments.text: Ah ok... Thanks for the friction mentioned. I realised it was the cage - Front and Back which were compressed against the mechanisms. The holes where the pin sits were not enlarged, hence it has a tight grip. comments.text:
Hi YCheez. I think the material doesn't matter, as long as the pieces are accurately printed, and critical surfaces are smooth (gear teeth, escapement teeth). It will work with PLA, PETG, or ABS. If materials are mixed, you need to consider different shrinking factors especially with ABS. Low friction is more relevant for fast moving components like the whole tourbillon. Minutes gear is already quite slow, and hours is even more slower. The explanation for this is simple physics:
power = speed * force
Whereas force is directly related with friction. The hours wheel doesn't require much power even if friction was high. Anyway back to the material: The mainspring is the only part that won't work with PLA! However ABS will work as well as PETG.

I think that everything could have been done with M2 bolts, you need a mix of cheese and countersunk heads. Didn't cut the thread, I let the bolt do the cutting after drilling it to just under size. comments.text:
The friction will almost certainly be in the tourbillon, that is the most sensitive section. All the components must spin freely without excessive wobble.
Also, I first built the tourbillon without the anchor or hair spring, mounted it in the watch body and checked that it rotated freely. There was a small section of the gear in the case_centre_plate that had some friction. A little work with a file cleared it. Then I re-assembled the tourbillon with all the parts.

comments.text: My balance wheel oscillates approximately 3-5 seconds, when started with a 90° angle. If yours oscillates only for 2 seconds, you probably need to work with pins and drills. I peeled off the bottom layer from all the escapement gear teeth in order to remove the elephant foot. Finally check the anchor pallets. These are quite small and material quality, nozzle age, print settings have a big influence on their accurate shape.
comments.author: scottyk

comments.text: Could you elaborate on that "peeling the layer off bottom of gear teeth?"   Was this done only to the teeth itself, or the entire gear?  When you say bottom layer are referring to a actual layer of the part or a raft of some sort?

comments.text: Only the escapement teeth. It's important that ALL the teeth have exactly the same length and shape at the tip. Or the ticking will be irregular. An "elephant foot" is usually not very regular. I started cutting with the knife, but suddenly the bottom layer just came off (maybe a printer malfunction?)
comments.author: scottyk

comments.text: I was doing some more experimenting last night with first layer heights, and when printing with .08 layer height and .1 first layer height it helps tremendously with the elephant foot problem. I have also started printing parts 1 piece at a time to eliminate nubs from the extruder jumping from part to part. Hopefully get tourbillion try #2 tonight, see if I make this thing tick finally!
comments.author: TheGoofy

I have everything moving friction free but the fit could be tighter.  I will get some proper size drills tonight and try to print one part at a time slowly in hopes the anchor will come out higher quality this time. comments.text: Great work! May I ask why you changed your modelling software from your previous project from Blender to Autodesk Fusion 360?
comments.author: ClockGeek

comments.text: I wanted to learn something new :-) ... Blender is great if you don't do several design iterations. If your design is a complex shaped object, and at the end you realize, that earlier a hole for a screw was positioned wrongly, you're lost with a chaotic mesh. Boolean modifiers don't really help if there are more than 3 primitives combined. In Fusion 360 iterative design is much easier: you just click the hole, delete it and make a new hole. Or alternatively you can even scroll back in history, and re-position it. I was also surprised about the rendering quality - it looks very nice just out of the box, while in Blender you have to heavily tune light sources and materials. AND Fusion 360 is free for hobbyists for 3 years, and affordable for more professionals.
comments.author: ClockGeek

title: mBot Ultrasonic Servo Mount Bracket Faceplate Makeblock

description.text: Since most of the ultrasonic sensor mounts that I found on Thingiverse were for a different sized sensor, I made one for my Makeblock mBot. This bracket is designed to mount the mBot Makeblock Ultrasonic Sensor to the Makeblock Servo, to enable the servo to control the direction of the sensor. If your sensor is a slightly different size, you can customize the bracket to fit. I use this in conjunction with: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1249439 to attach it to the mBot. Also, feel free to experiment with the other parameters of the design to create a unique look. I found that there is enough support for the sensor with only the center of the "eyes" being held, instead of the bracket completely covering the face. I used OpenSCAD to design the part, and this is the first piece I have designed this way. Please let me know if it works for you.

comments.text:
Few more questions...What's the benefit of using the pg35l micro extruder versus using a Bowden extruder? It seems like it's pretty simple but you're probably moving around more weight. Are you happy with it? Are you using 1.75mm or 3mm filament?
Thanks,
Brian
comments.author: cpdude

comments.text: direct drive extruders are much better than Bowden. Less retraction needed and more accurate. less Ooze and just generally more accurate extrusion. The extra weight is why I used beefed up arms, and seems to be fine for the speeds I print at. Less weight would probably mean I could print faster but that really does not make as much difference as one would think. I use 3mm filament too which Bowdens have problems with. I currently can print at 120mm/sec infill and 80mm/sec perimeters and 300mm/sec fast moves.
comments.author: cpdude

comments.text: Hey Jim,  I'm completely confused by the gt2-carriage on github.  I'm going with Makerslide and the Standard Wheel Carriage Plates.  None of the holes seem to match.  Also do you have any pictures of how the belts will fasten to the carriage?  Thanks!  Brian

comments.text:
there are several options,here is a photo of the printed gt2 makerslide carriage http://flic.kr/p/hP9NYghttp://flic.kr/p/hP9NYg that is carriage-plate.scad.
If using the inventables carriage plates then the one to use is gt2-carriage.scad. it has two posts to wrap the gt2 belt around, you need to run an m3 bolt through each post to make it strong enough, then use zip ties to fasten the gt2 around itself. It should bolt to the carriage plat when the plate is vertical.

description.text:
I've always been fascinated by the world of robots since I was a kid, especially I would like to make and watch them move. Now through 3D printing I have finally the power to make this happen; I can design them, print the parts, assembly them and animate.
So after EEZYbotARM .... EEZYbotDELTA ( 2 pass the ball 2 :-) )
Following the aims of my previous robot arm
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015238
I developed a second one. This one belongs to the family of "spider" Delta robots. In industrial applications it is mainly used for assembly purposes (Pick and Place) videos:
https://youtu.be/mR6eCmtux_g
https://youtu.be/oGUTnrtlgHw 24/01/16 new video about controlling the bot via bluetooth an smartphone
https://youtu.be/TCjfZnsRWU4
code and app free
http://www.instructables.com/id/Android-APP-to-Control-a-3DPrinted-Robot/ Delta bots have the advantage that they have common parts for all the driving items (normally 3 or 4) thats simplify the construction.
I try to follow the philosophy of my previous thing that must be: small, cheap and easy to assemble but this time I had to use bigger servo (mg995) for the three main arms so this makes it a little bigger ( 400 x 450 x 450h mm of occupied volume comprehensive of structure).
http://www.servodatabase.com/servo/towerpro/mg995
I kept a smaller sg90 servo for the gripper.
http://www.servodatabase.com/servo/towerpro/sg90
I have added also a structure to hang up the main body. It is a mixed construction and is made with printed parts, and Ø16 mm aluminum pipes that I get from a local hardware store. This is a ready-made solution, but you can make your own.
Also in this case I made a printed ramp to make an handling "demo loop" that can be watched in videos. for the assembly have a look at my instructable here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/EEZYbotDELTA-3Dprinted-Robot/ COMMERCIAL ITEMS BOM (I use metric hardware) n°3 MG995 servo
n°1 sg90s servo
n°3 604zz ball bearing
n°12 Uniball Traxxas M4x17 Crawler/Scaler ... (bought on ebay)
n°3 Ø16 x 1 l=220 mm aluminum pipes
n°3 Ø16 x 1 l=330 mm aluminum pipes
n° 6 M4 x 200 mm long threaded rods
n°15 M3 nuts
n°6 M3 x 14 TCEI screw (receessed hex head)
n°6 M3 x 20 TCEI screw (receessed hex head)
n°6 3x15 self tapping screw
n1 400 x 450 mm plywood sheet ELECTRONICS
Like already explained in my previous robot arm, there are several ways to control it but I do not want to provide ready made solution.
The purpouse is just that, produce a sufficiently reliable and ready hardware to allow users to explore they own way to control it.
In any case if you are, like me, alien for what concerns the electronic parts, and you need the fastest and easyest way to obtain results in controlling the bot, I suggest the Pololu Mini Maestro card. https://www.pololu.com/product/1352
The card is provided with a free downlodable software that give you the power to drive with an easy grafical interface all the servos moving manually slides. In the mean time you are able to set the values of speed and acceleration for any singular item. You can also build sequences of commands in a easy way, store them in the controller o get the code automatically.

comments.text: Bella e molto semplice ... complimentoni ...una considerazione .. applicando il movimento del servo a una sola delle due flange che compongono il braccio di leva, avrai poca precisione e oscillazioni dovute alla flessione della plastica. Nella prossima versione potresti collegare le due flange con un albero unico e portare il movimento con due ingranaggi, uno sull'albero e l'altro sul servo. ;)
comments.author: SgaboLab

comments.text:
Il cuscinetto sull'altro lato unito alle controventature "T" innestate nei bracci, avevano appunto l'intento di ridurre le torsioni dovute alla trazione asimmetrica.
Il tutto però deve fare poi i conti con relativa qualità dei servo (volutamente economici) e a tutto quello che c'è a valle a partire dalle barre filettate M4. Per non dimenticare che, con la scheda Pololu, gestisci con un solo valore sia accelerazione che decelerazione quindi devi trovare un compromesso
Ma questo l'ho fatto per fini di studio, per capire dove potevo arrivare con i materiali, i soldi e il tempo (notturno) che avevo a disposizione.
Cmq grazie!
comments.author: SgaboLab

comments.text:
ho visto il cuscinetto a bilanciare, solo che per esperienza personale nel muovere bracci meccanici applicando la forza in maniera sbilanciata, se il braccio non ha una vera rigidita, questo crea problemi.
Vedendo anche l'altro braccio robotico che hai fatto mi viene da suggerirti una cosa per i giunti: se prendi un tubo di ottone con diametro interno 4-5mm, tagliandone la lunghezza necessaria e conbinandoila con una vite del diametro quasi uguale (m3 ~ 3,8mm, m4 ~ 4,8mm) puoi crearti delle economiche bronzine per i prossimi modelli ;)
Pienamente d'accordo poi anche sulle tue considerazioni .. anche io ho soppravalutato la rigidita e resistenza della plastica .. ho fatto un motore brushless che mi è esploso in mano .. dai un occhiata al mio canale youtube ;)
Buona progettazione .. sono curiuso di vedere il prossimo ;)
